page.title: 04Going Fishing
page.content: Today Teena,her Dad and Grandad are after a rich harvest of shrimps. This type of fishing involves towing a bag shaped trawl net behind the tractor at low tide, scooping the shrimps from the shallow water. They stop regularly to empty the catch into boxes. On other days,depending on the state of the tide or the season,they fish for{cockles}or{flukes}(flounders).This local word,fluke,is the origin of the village name,Flookburgh. Cockles are caught by rocking a big wooden frame,a Jumbo,on the sand.This brings to cockles up to the surface, where they are raked up and bagged. To catch flukes, standing nets are staked on the bay, often far away from shore, ready to trap the flukes on the outgoing tide.Then the fishermen have a race to get the fish before the seagulls.
